title: R44430
content: The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) administers programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) of 1994, providing financial and technical assistance to improve criminal justice responses to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for OVW was $489 million, with proposed increases for various grants and initiatives. The Obama Administration proposed funding two new initiatives: reducing firearm lethality in domestic violence cases and enhancing colleges' and universities' responses to campus sexual assault. Congress adopted a $326 million transfer from the Crime Victims Fund for OVW, but did not fully support other proposals. Funding for grants to encourage arrests in domestic violence cases and enforce protection orders was increased, but not to the level proposed. Congress also maintained funding for STOP grants at the FY2016 level. The Obama Administration requested a $154 million budget for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017, a 32.8% increase from FY2016. This account funds the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the National Institute of Justice, with additional funding for forensic sciences improvement and new initiatives like a clearinghouse for evidence-based programs and incident-based crime statistics. The Obama Administration proposed a $154 million budget for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017, a 32.8% increase from FY2016. This account funds the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the National Institute of Justice, with additional funding for forensic sciences improvement and new initiatives. Congress provided $89 million for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017, a decrease of -23.3% due to funding being moved to the Community Oriented Policing Services account. The State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account includes funding for various grant programs to improve criminal justice systems. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for this account was $1.098 billion, 22.1% less than the FY2016 appropriation. Funding for the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program was proposed to be eliminated. The Obama Administration proposed cuts to various programs including SCAAP, Coverdell Forensic Sciences, grants for trafficking victims, John R. Justice program, and tribal assistance. They also planned to redirect funds to support tribal justice programs and increase funding for reentry initiatives. Additionally, reductions were proposed for JAG program, National Criminal History Improvement program, and DNA backlog reduction initiatives. The Obama Administration proposed increasing funding for various programs under the Law Enforcement Assistance account, including reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for substance abuse treatment, and programs for people with mental illness in the criminal justice system. They also requested funding for new programs such as the Byrne Incentive Grant program, Byrne Competitive Grant program, and grants for courts and justice agencies to improve fairness and community trust. The Obama Administration proposed increasing funding for various programs under the Law Enforcement Assistance account, including reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for substance abuse treatment, and programs for people with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Congress reduced funding for the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account by 9.1%, or $128 million, for FY2017. Available funding for the JAG program decreased from $347 million for FY2016 to $335 million for FY2017. The Consolidated Appropriations Act eliminates funding for tribal assistance programs (-$30 million). The Appropriations Act eliminates funding for tribal assistance programs (-$30 million) but authorizes DOJ to use up to 7% of funding from other accounts for tribal justice assistance programs. Congress allocated $103 million for an opioid initiative, with most funding coming from existing programs like Drug Courts, Veterans Treatment Courts, and programs for individuals with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Additionally, $13 million was provided for programs authorized by the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act of 2016 under the opioids initiative. The Juvenile Justice Programs account received a funding increase request of $334 million for FY2017, including proposals to increase funding for various programs under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act. The Obama Administration also requested funding restoration for the Juvenile Accountability Block Grants and proposed a Smart on Juvenile Justice Initiative with a $20 million budget. The Obama Administration proposed funding reductions for youth mentoring grants, child abuse programs, and missing and exploited children programs in FY2017. Congress appropriated $247 million for Juvenile Justice Programs, an 8.6% reduction from FY2016. Funding cuts were made for JJDPA Part B state formula grants, youth mentoring grants, and Title V grants. Congress also funded the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative as a set-aside from the Title V grant program, but declined to fund new programs proposed by the Obama Administration. The COPS Office awards grants to law enforcement agencies for hiring new officers and community policing training. The Obama Administration requested a $74 million increase in funding for the COPS program in FY2017, with a focus on hiring new officers, community policing training, and crime-fighting technologies. Congress appropriated $222 million for the COPS account, including a $3 million increase for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program. Funding for the hiring program remained unchanged at $137 million after set-asides were accounted for. The Obama Administration requested a $74 million increase in funding for the COPS program in FY2017, with a focus on hiring new officers, community policing training, and crime-fighting technologies. Congress appropriated $222 million for the COPS account, including a $3 million increase for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program. P.L. 115-31 requires funding for the Regional Information Sharing System (RISS) to be transferred to OJP. Congress also set aside $8 million from the COPS hiring program for the POLICE Act of 2016 (P.L. 114-199), allowing grants to be used for active shooter training. The Administration requested $500 million for the 21st Century Justice Initiative in FY2017, aiming to invest $5 billion over 10 years in criminal justice reform efforts. The initiative would focus on reducing crime, reversing practices leading to unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust. States could use the funding to address these objectives in their adult and juvenile systems. The Obama Administration proposed funding increases for the COPS program in FY2017, focusing on hiring new officers, community policing training, and crime-fighting technologies. Additionally, they requested $500 million for the 21st Century Justice Initiative to invest in criminal justice reform efforts, including reducing crime and unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust. Congress did not provide funding for this initiative.
